bibl.title: Letter from Willys M. Monroe to Henry Rose Carter, [June 1923]

div1.p: Carter responds to Monroe's letter that asks several questions about the epidemiology of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Willys M. Monroe to Henry Rose Carter, [June 1923]
div1.opener:
Book
I. H. B.
Monroe.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I have just read a mimeographed copy of the Section
on Epidemiology of your History of Yellow fever, and as there are a few
points that I have been wondering about for some time which I had hoped
would be cleared up in your book, but which you probably thought too
unimportant to mention, I am taking the liberty of writing to you for
a word or two of explanation.

When I was working with Dr. Connor in Mexico in 1921
and 1922, I heard a great deal of the condition which you designate re
gional endemicity, and which Dr. Connor calls “hacienda infection”, At
the time I gained the impression that such a condition could exist only
where the combined populations of the various units of the area would be
equal to that of a single large town, travel conditions being such that
the area is a unit in reality. For example, I can readily see that the
Papalo-apan Valley in the southern part of the State of Vera Cruz would
be considered as an area of regional endemicity, for it has a larte popul
ation with river communication, and the temperature is such that there are
throughout the year, and I think uniformly, active A. aegypti mosquitoes.

But I have been wondering if certain regions with
not
a much smaller total population could also be considered areas of
regional endemicity, if certain other factors were variable. According to
your postulate B, three factors are necessary for the continued existence
of Yellow fever in any place (1) The causative organism of the disease,
(2) Active A. aegypti mosquitoes, and (3) Men susceptible to the disease.
Granted the presence of the first factor, would not the continuance of
the disease depend not so much on the number of non-immunes, as on the
rate of exhaustion of non-immunes, which, it would seem to me, would dep
end on how closely the number of active A. aegypti mosquitoes approached
the critical number, a close approximation causing a low rate of exhausti
ion, but, on the other hand, a large excess of A. aegypti in the active
state causing a rapid exhaustion of the non-immune population.

In your discussion of the effects of temperature, Page 37, you
show the relation of the increase and decrease of Yellow fever to the rise
and fall of temperature as it applies to cities, and I assume that this
is due to the lessened mosquito breeding during the cooler weather.
Might not this lower rate of production of imagoes cause the disease to
continue in rural areas with populations so small that they would not be
considered endemic regions but rather epidemic, if the temperature were
the optimum for mosquito production?

I was working in Tampico during parts of 1921 and 1922, shortly
after there had been several epidemics in the country districts between
Tampico and Vera Cruz, where the winters were hardly severe enough to in-
terfere with mosquito production. These epidemics were controlled, perhaps
with the aid of anti-mosquito measures, perhaps by spontaneous eliminat
ion. After a year without any cases, control measures were discontinued
in Tampico, but just at the end of my stay there were rumors of cases up
the Panuco Valley, above Tampico. These, however, were disregarded after
inspections of the city of Panuco by both Dr. Connor and myself. Above
the city of Panuco there is a small but well populated district called
El Higo. In Tampico the production of adult A. aegypti is greatly reduced
in the winter. This I know from personal observation. El Higo has practi
cally the same latitude as Tampico, but it is at a slightly higher elevat
ion, so that the winter is even cooler. Just above El Higo there is an
other valley at Micos where I was unable to find A. aegypti breeding dur
ing the winter. After I left Tampico in 1922, several cases of Yellow
fever were imported from Panuco. Do you think that the regionvalley above Panuco
could have remained as a region of endemicity, the lessened mosquito pro
duction, due to the cool weather, compensating for the relative paucity
of non-immunes, by causing the rate of exhaustion to be very low?

I have recently returned from Colombia, S. A., where Dr. White
is investigating a reported outbreak of Yellow fever in Bucaramanga. I
have not seen Bucaramanga, but I have seen in Departments adjacent to and
very much like Santander, valleys, where because of the altitude, condit
ions analagous to winter conditions in El Higo exist throughout the year,
and mosquito production must be greatly retarded. Could not endemic condit
ions prevail for many years in such a valley where the high percentage of
non-immunes would lead one to believe that the disease would be epidemic?
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Willys M. Monroe.
International Health Board Dr. H. R. Carter,
Washington, D. C.
